title.rendered: Explore Job Roles: Soil and Plant Scientists

content.rendered:
What is a Soil and Plant Scientist?

Soil and Plant Scientists are concerned with soil composition and how to treat it for the best results. They use their knowledge of plants and soil to create better methods for yields and to prevent any issues with possible invasive bugs or weeds.

Where does a Soil and Plant Scientist work?

  • Laboratories
  • Field offices
  • Kitchens

How much does a Soil and Plant Scientist make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for a Soil and Plant Scientists is $46,878.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Soil and Plant Scientists?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing this career path.

  • Agricultural majors
  • Horticulture science majors
  • Biology majors
Search Soil and Plant Scientist job opportunities on Handshake.

Soil and Plant Scientist skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Soil and Plant Scientists succeed in their work:

  • Strong knowledge of scientific principles and practices
  • Basic comprehensive knowledge of soil and plant language
  • Openness to learn and understand

What are some common questions about Soil and Plant Scientists?

Q: What are some daily tasks for Soil and Plant Scientists?

A: Research plant history and physiology, study chemical effects on crops and soil, observe and control plant growth and pest contamination–to name a few.
